body: A line must be drawn at some point though to delegate to tmux. I'm wondering if implementing scrollback search in a mode would be a slippery slope to implementing something like termite's entire selection mode, and whether that's in scope simplicity and performance-wise here.

Search is one of the reasons I will keep using tmux even after scrollback is merged, assuming #1000 is implemented too. 

I was considering to report this exact feature request myself a few days ago, but then I thought of what search capabilities I use today in tmux, and I realized that reimplementing them natively in alacritty would be too expensive, so I don't think vanilla alacritty will ever suffice my needs. 

I support the feature request, perhaps for many people that all they need, but here's for the reference the list of search capabilities that I identified as currently used by me with tmux:

- Incremental search (not type-then-search)
- Prepared search queries (e.g. `‚ùØ` is my prompt character, and I have a tmux shortcut that starts a search for the character `‚ùØ`, which allows me to jump to previous prompts in one key press)
- Visual selection (i.e. once you find something in the scrollback history (e.g. start of a log entry), use keyboard shortcuts to expand the selection (e.g. to select the entire log entry)
- Operations on the visual selection (via `tmux-yank` plugin):
    - Copy the selection to clipboard
    - Paste the selection to the prompt directly without copying it to clipboard
- Fuzzy-search + smart text blocks extraction (via `extrakto` plugin):
    - Open URL in browser
    - Open file path in the text editor
    - Copy to clipboard
    - and many more.

And after I saw this list, I realized that this is too much for alacritty, so I'll always be using tmux.

I'm not saying something like a vim-mode might solve all of those. But it kinda would.

Imo this is out of scope for 1.0 and earlier though.

All of these a kinda _possible_ even with a simple scrollback search and then grabbing a mouse to select what you need, a simple vim-mode would allow to avoid reaching for the mouse, but the experience would still not be as nice/simple as the approach that I currently have, no incremental or fuzzy search, no prepared search queries, etc.

By the way, do you want to create a new feature request for the post-scrollback era: implement vim-mode? üòõ

Incremental search and fuzzy search would be no problem with a vim mode and a bit of regex.

I've actually never used vim mode much with termite. Imo it's useful for stuff like selection though.
Maybe "implement vim mode" is worthy of being a RFC? To invite discussion
I think yes, please create the issue for it.

We might consider using [ripgrep's internals](https://docs.rs/grep/0.1.7/grep/index.html) if we decide to add this. Primary challenges with supporting search:

- Scrollback history would need to have a `String` representation to make it searchable
- If we want to support searches across line breaks, we would need to map String bytes offsets to lines and columns
- Keeping active region in a searchable String would be expensive since it can be updated very frequently.

I just want to mention that I have no plans on using tmux on a regular basis. I know that most people here use it, and that Alacritty was (at least originally) designed to work assumeing you were using tmux, but... I feel this terminal has great potential on its own, and for some features like this one (imo) the complexity gain is worth it.

issue.title: No Wrap Mode
issue.body:
I frequently run commands that have outputs which wrap text onto newlines (as we all do), the way we handle this today is the correct default behavior, but it would be neat to have the ability to active a "no wrap mode" where the arrow keys (h,j,k,l too) would scroll around the text. This would remove a very common pattern of rerunning the last command piped to `less -S`.

I understand this project is resistant to new features (for good reason), so I won't be offended if this is closed in the name of complexity. I do think this would be a relatively small complexity add if we are already thinking of adding modes as in #262, and #1017.

body: This is a neat way to do things without adding a whole mode. https://sw.kovidgoyal.net/kitty/#the-scrollback-buffer

@nixpulvis That would definitely be a possibility, however searching through the buffer itself shouldn't be extremely difficult either.

So the question is more which of these is simpler for the user and for maintenance. I think with these things considered just dumping the grid into a pager is a bit more straight-forward and doesn't introduce a lot of new things into Alacritty.

issue.title: RFC: Dump scrollback buffer to new instance of alacritty running a pager
issue.body:
This is a potential compromise for fixing #1017.  Currently being unable to search the scrollback buffer severely limits its usefulness but at the same it's questionable whether this should be implemented directly in alacritty itself.

This PR adds an action to spawn a new instance of alacritty with a user specified pager and then dump the contents of the scrollback buffer into the stdin of the new instance.  This neatly sidesteps the issue of having to implement search functionality in alacritty itself while giving users the freedom to use whichever pager best suits their needs.  The default is `less` but there's nothing stopping someone from using an editor like `vim` as their pager instead.

The contents of the scrollback buffer are first converted into a string (by iterating over every occupied cell) before being written out, which means we end up with a copy of the buffer in memory.  However since this is something that is only done in response to explicit user action, it shouldn't end up getting out of hand.

This is probably not fit for merging in its current state but I wanted to ask if this is something that would be accepted upstream before spending time cleaning it up.

body:
I believe that "selection mode" was mentioned here: https://github.com/jwilm/alacritty/issues/262 and this would for sure solve that issue. IMO issue should be linked.

For similar reason as @maximbaz mentioned, I use `tmux` only because of "copy mode" search and modal scrolling. For that purpose I've 2 key bindings to enter that mode: regular and another which automaticly puts me in "seach-backward". For me this is crutial because otherwise I would drown myself in criptic keybindings just to manage separation for `alacritty`, `i3` and `vim`.

@jwilm what about allowing rendering and export of the terminal scrollback to a file or piping to a process to do the search? Would that be easier and/or faster than trying to maintain a separate String representation? I am currently moving over from `termite` because Alacritty's lower latency is very attractive, but inability to search my scrollback (the only thing I use termite's vim-mode for) is very limiting.

issue.title: Add regex scrollback buffer search
issue.body:
This adds initial support for regex scrollback buffer search. While
searching should already be fully functional, the match is currently
only logged to stdout and not displayed in Alacritty.

However the searching should already behave as intended.

Fixes #3672.
Fixes #1017.

There are a lot of edgecases with this PR that need to be tested, I went through all of them but I doubt I've tested all permutations. So here's a list with things that would be useful to test:
 - Search from vi mode starting in last line
 - Search from vi mode above last line
 - Search without vi mode
 - Forward search
 - Backwards search
 - Goto match next start/end, previous start/end
 - Resize during search
 - Message bar
 - Start search while scrolled up
 - Search without history
 - Search with history and normal cursor at bottom
 - Search with history and normal cursor not at bottom (ctrl+l)
 - Immediate search while typing with match < 1000 lines away
 - Delayed search while typing with match > 1000 lines away

There are a few features I've intentionally left out that we should likely add in the future. I'll create issues for them as soon as this PR is merged:
 - Moving the cursor inside the search bar
 - Anchored searches using ^ and $
